message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: On Reasoning about Values
Paper Abstract: Abstract This essay is a contribution to the logic of intentions, and to Sellars’s project of interpreting the moral “ought” in terms of “shall.” Using “shall” as an operator to denote the expression of an intention (e.g., “Shall [I go to the park]”), Sellars outlines a number of logical principles which must govern inferences among such intention-expressions. However, the moral “ought” cannot be analyzed in terms of ordinary intention-expressions, for the latter lack the necessary elements of intersubjectivity. Sellars argues that a particular kind of intentions—we-intentions—can have the requisite kind of intersubjectivity, and offers an account of what distinguishes we-intentions from ordinary, egocentric intentions. He concludes with reflections on the moral community, arguing that it is in virtue of sharing the intrinsically reasonable intention Shall [each of us do that which, in the circumstances, promotes the happiness of each and every one of us, all relevant things considered]. that one is a member of the moral community, a community we must treat as comprising rational beings, generally.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Modal logic ought"

Links: [{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"Deontic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deontic_logic"},{"title":"Deontic modality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deontic_modality"},{"title":"Modality (semantics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modality_(linguistics)"},{"title":"S5 (modal logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S5_(modal_logic)"},{"title":"Talk:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Normal modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normal_modal_logic"},{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Modal operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_operator"},{"title":"Alan Ross Anderson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Ross_Anderson"}]

Here are the search results for "Modal logic ought":

The search returns information about modal logic and its relationship to "ought" statements. Key findings include:

**Ought and Modal Logic**

The idea that "ought implies can" is an embodiment of a Kantian concept, which is fundamental to how modal logic handles normative statements.

**Deontic Logic**

Deontic logic is the field of philosophical logic that is concerned with obligation, permission, and related concepts, or alternatively, a formal system that attempts to capture the essential logical features of these concepts.(no content)A deontic logic typically uses OA to mean it is obligatory that A (or it ought to be (the case) that A).

**Key Distinction**

In deontic modal logic, what ought to be true can be false, which distinguishes it from epistemic modal logic where truth is assumed.

**Deontic Modality**

Deontic modality is a linguistic modality that indicates how the world ought to be according to certain norms, expectations, speaker desires, etc.

The search results show that modal logic provides a formal framework for analyzing statements involving "ought," primarily through the subfield of deontic logic.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Intersubjectivity philosophy"

Links: [{"title":"Intersubjectivity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersubjectivity"},{"title":"Intersubjective psychoanalysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersubjective_psychoanalysis"},{"title":"Intersubjective verifiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersubjective_verifiability"},{"title":"Subjectivity and objectivity (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjectivity_and_objectivity_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Other (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Other_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Integral theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integral_theory"},{"title":"Phenomenology (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenomenology_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Center for Subjectivity Research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Subjectivity_Research"},{"title":"Problem of other minds - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Problem_of_other_minds"},{"title":"Interaction theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of intersubjectivity in philosophy:

## Definition and Overview

Intersubjectivity describes the shared understanding that emerges from interpersonal interactions.(no content)Contemporarily, intersubjectivity is the major topic in both the analytic and the continental traditions of philosophy.

## Philosophical Significance

Intersubjectivity is considered crucial not only at the relational level but also at the epistemological and even metaphysical levels. For example, intersubjectivity is postulated as playing a role in establishing the truth of propositions, and constituting the intersubjective agreement of an experience of an object.

## Key Philosophical Problem

A central concern in consciousness studies of the past 50 years is the so-called problem of other minds, which asks how we can justify our belief that people have minds much like our own and predict others' mind-states and behavior, as our experience shows we often can.(no content)The specific subject within phenomenology studying other minds is intersubjectivity.

## Phenomenological Perspective

In phenomenology, intersubjectivity constitutes objectivity (i.e., what one experiences as objective is experienced as being intersubjectively available – available to all other subjects).(no content)Edmund Husserl applied the concept of the Other as the basis for intersubjectivity, the psychological relations among people.

## Contemporary Theories

Three major contemporary theories of intersubjectivity are theory theory, simulation theory, and interaction theory.(no content)Interaction theory supports the notion of the direct perception of the other's intentions and emotions during intersubjective encounters.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Wilfrid Sellars philosopher"

Links: [{"title":"Wilfrid Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilfrid_Sellars"},{"title":"Willem deVries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willem_deVries"},{"title":"Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sellars"},{"title":"Carus Lectures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carus_Lectures"},{"title":"Roy Wood Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Sellars"},{"title":"Analytic philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_philosophy"},{"title":"List of philosophers of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_philosophers_of_mind"},{"title":"Herbert Feigl - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Feigl"},{"title":"List of philosophers born in the 20th century - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_philosophers_born_in_the_20th_century"},{"title":"John McDowell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McDowell"}]

Here's information about Wilfrid Sellars, the philosopher:

## Overview

Wilfrid Sellars (1912–1989) was an American philosopher, and he "revolutionized both the content and the method of philosophy in the United States".

## Education and Career

Sellars was educated at the University of Michigan (BA, 1933), the University at Buffalo, and Oriel College, Oxford (1934–1937), where he was a Rhodes Scholar, obtaining his highest earned degree, an MA, in 1940.(no content)He taught at the University of Iowa (1938–1946), the University of Minnesota (1947–1958), Yale University (1958–1963), and from 1963 until his death, at the University of Pittsburgh.

## Major Philosophical Contributions

Sellars is well known as a critic of foundationalist epistemology—the "Myth of the Given" as he called it.(no content)His philosophical works are more generally directed toward the ultimate goal of reconciling intuitive ways of describing the world (both those of common sense and traditional philosophy) with a thoroughly naturalist, scientific account of reality.(no content)Sellars's goal of a synoptic philosophy that unites the everyday and scientific views of reality is the foundation and archetype of what is sometimes called the Pittsburgh School, whose members include Brandom, John McDowell, and John Haugeland.

## Influence

Robert Brandom, his junior colleague at Pittsburgh, named Sellars and Willard Van Orman Quine as the two most profound and important philosophers of their generation.

Links: [{"title":"Wilfrid Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilfrid_Sellars"},{"title":"Willem deVries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Willem_deVries"},{"title":"Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sellars"},{"title":"Carus Lectures - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carus_Lectures"},{"title":"Roy Wood Sellars - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roy_Sellars"},{"title":"Analytic philosophy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Analytic_philosophy"},{"title":"List of philosophers of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_philosophers_of_mind"},{"title":"Herbert Feigl - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Herbert_Feigl"},{"title":"List of philosophers born in the 20th century - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_philosophers_born_in_the_20th_century"},{"title":"John McDowell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_McDowell"}]

Here's information about Wilfrid Sellars, the philosopher:

## Overview

Wilfrid Sellars (1912–1989) was an American philosopher, and he "revolutionized both the content and the method of philosophy in the United States".

## Education and Career

Sellars was educated at the University of Michigan (BA, 1933), the University at Buffalo, and Oriel College, Oxford (1934–1937), where he was a Rhodes Scholar, obtaining his highest earned degree, an MA, in 1940.(no content)He taught at the University of Iowa (1938–1946), the University of Minnesota (1947–1958), Yale University (1958–1963), and from 1963 until his death, at the University of Pittsburgh.

## Major Philosophical Contributions

Sellars is well known as a critic of foundationalist epistemology—the "Myth of the Given" as he called it.(no content)His philosophical works are more generally directed toward the ultimate goal of reconciling intuitive ways of describing the world (both those of common sense and traditional philosophy) with a thoroughly naturalist, scientific account of reality.(no content)Sellars's goal of a synoptic philosophy that unites the everyday and scientific views of reality is the foundation and archetype of what is sometimes called the Pittsburgh School, whose members include Brandom, John McDowell, and John Haugeland.

## Influence

Robert Brandom, his junior colleague at Pittsburgh, named Sellars and Willard Van Orman Quine as the two most profound and important philosophers of their generation.

Web search results for query: "Rational agent philosophy"

Links: [{"title":"Rational agent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_agent"},{"title":"Rational choice model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_choice_theory"},{"title":"Action (philosophy) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_(philosophy)"},{"title":"Causal decision theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_decision_theory"},{"title":"Moral agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_agency"},{"title":"Kantian ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kantian_ethics"},{"title":"Noëlle McAfee - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No%C3%ABlle_McAfee"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of rational agent philosophy:

## Definition and Core Concept

A rational agent or rational being is a person or entity that always aims to perform optimal actions based on given premises and information.(no content)A rational agent can be anything that makes decisions, typically a person, firm, machine, or software.

## Disciplines and Applications

The concept of rational agents can be found in various disciplines such as artificial intelligence, cognitive science, decision theory, economics, ethics, game theory, and the study of practical reason.

## Rational Choice Theory

The basic premise of rational choice theory is that the decisions made by individual actors will collectively produce aggregate social behaviour.(no content)At its most basic level, behavior is rational if it is reflective and consistent (across time and different choice situations).

## Key Philosophical Perspectives

**Economics and Moral Philosophy:** The idea of a rational agent is important to the philosophy of utilitarianism, as detailed by philosopher Jeremy Bentham's theory of the felicific calculus, also known as the hedonistic calculus.

**Action and Rationality:** Only actions with good reasons are considered rational.

**Decision Theory:** Causal decision theory (CDT) is a school of thought within decision theory which states that, when a rational agent is confronted with a set of possible actions, one should select the action which causes the best outcome in expectation.

**Moral Agency:** Most philosophers suggest only rational beings, who can reason and form self-interested judgments, are capable of being moral agents.

Links: [{"title":"Philosophy of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_logic"},{"title":"Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic"},{"title":"Outline of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_logic"},{"title":"History of logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_logic"},{"title":"Paul Lorenzen - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Lorenzen"},{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"Philosophical views of Bertrand Russell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bertrand_Russell's_philosophical_views"},{"title":"Axiomatic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiomatic_system"},{"title":"Formal proof - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_proof"},{"title":"George Edward Hughes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Edward_Hughes"}]

Here are the search results for "Formal logic philosophy":

## Overview

Formal logic is only interested in the form of arguments, expressed in a formal language, and focuses on deductive inferences.(no content)Logic is the formal science of using reason and is considered a branch of both philosophy and mathematics and to a lesser extent computer science.

## Key Characteristics

Informal logic examines arguments expressed in natural language whereas formal logic uses formal language.(no content)The essential feature of this field is the use of formal languages to express the ideas whose logical validity is being studied.

## Related Philosophical Disciplines

Philosophy of logic is the philosophical discipline studying the scope and nature of logic. It examines many presuppositions implicit in logic, like how to define its basic concepts or the metaphysical assumptions associated with them. It is also concerned with how to classify logical systems and considers the ontological commitments they incur.(no content)Philosophical logic is one of the areas within the philosophy of logic. It studies the application of logical methods to philosophical problems in fields like metaphysics, ethics, and epistemology.

## Historical Development

Logic revived in the mid-nineteenth century, at the beginning of a revolutionary period when the subject developed into a rigorous and formal discipline which took as its exemplar the exact method of proof used in mathematics. The development of the modern "symbolic" or "mathematical" logic during this period by the likes of Boole, Frege, Russell, and Peano is the most significant in the two-thousand-year history of logic.

Web search results for query: "Moral community ethics"

Links: [{"title":"Communitarianism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communitarianism"},{"title":"Ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_community"},{"title":"Morality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Morality"},{"title":"Ethical relationship - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethical_relationship"},{"title":"Ethics of care - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_care"},{"title":"Moral agency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_agency"},{"title":"Moral foundations theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_foundations_theory"},{"title":"Role ethics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Role_ethics"},{"title":"Science of morality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_landscapes"},{"title":"Moral psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moral_psychology"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of "Moral community ethics":

## Key Concepts

**Ethics of Community in Communitarianism**

Communities can be defined with reasonable precision as having two characteristics: first, a web of affect-laden relationships among a group of individuals, relationships that often crisscross and reinforce one another, and second, a measure of commitment to a set of shared values, norms, and meanings, and a shared history and identity.

Good societies rely on a shared moral culture beyond merely neutral rules and procedures. The moral character of individuals tends to degrade over time unless that character is continually and communally reinforced through the community's "moral voice", defined as the informal sanction of other members.

**The Ethical Community in Moral Development**

Lawrence Kohlberg and Carol Gilligan developed a descriptive ethics of relationship conduct in what they called the ethical community or just community, which was a community of practice with a core epistemic community of those trusted to define and resolve disputes between members and facilitate the growth of moral development.

**Ethics of Care Perspective**

The ethics of care is a normative ethical theory that holds that moral action centers on interpersonal relationships and care or benevolence as a virtue. This approach emphasizes responding to individuals within community relationships rather than applying generalized universal standards.

**Role Ethics and Community**

In Confucian role ethics, morality is based on a person's fulfillment of a role, such as that of a parent or a child, and these roles are established as relationships and are not individualistic.

Communities can be defined with reasonable precision as having two characteristics: first, a web of affect-laden relationships among a group of individuals, relationships that often crisscross and reinforce one another, and second, a measure of commitment to a set of shared values, norms, and meanings, and a shared history and identity.

Good societies rely on a shared moral culture beyond merely neutral rules and procedures. The moral character of individuals tends to degrade over time unless that character is continually and communally reinforced through the community's "moral voice", defined as the informal sanction of other members.

**The Ethical Community in Moral Development**

Lawrence Kohlberg and Carol Gilligan developed a descriptive ethics of relationship conduct in what they called the ethical community or just community, which was a community of practice with a core epistemic community of those trusted to define and resolve disputes between members and facilitate the growth of moral development.

**Ethics of Care Perspective**

The ethics of care is a normative ethical theory that holds that moral action centers on interpersonal relationships and care or benevolence as a virtue. This approach emphasizes responding to individuals within community relationships rather than applying generalized universal standards.

**Role Ethics and Community**

In Confucian role ethics, morality is based on a person's fulfillment of a role, such as that of a parent or a child, and these roles are established as relationships and are not individualistic.

E. M. Anscombe - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G._E._M._Anscombe"},{"title":"Propositional attitude - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_attitude"},{"title":"Intentionality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intentionality"},{"title":"Theory of mind - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_mind"},{"title":"Michael Bratman - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Bratman"},{"title":"Philosophy of information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophy_of_information"},{"title":"Tractatus de Intellectus Emendatione - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tractatus_de_Intellectus_Emendatione"},{"title":"Telos - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telos"}]

Here are the search results for "Intention philosophy":

## Overview

An intention is a mental state in which a person commits themselves to a course of action.(no content)Intentions, like many other mental states, have intentionality: they represent possible states of affairs.

## Key Theories

Theories of intention try to capture the characteristic features of intentions. The belief-desire theory is the traditionally dominant approach.(no content)According to a simple version of it, having an intention is nothing but having a desire to perform a certain action and a belief that one will perform this action.(no content)Intentions are closely related to other mental states, like beliefs and desires. It is generally accepted that intentions involve some form of desire: the intended action is seen as good or desirable in some sense. This aspect makes it possible for intentions to motivate actions.

## Intentions and Actions

Actions contrast with events which merely happen to someone and are typically performed for a purpose and guided by an intention.(no content)The most common approach to this question defines actions in terms of intentions. According to Donald Davidson, an action is an event that is intentional under some description. On this view, it is a central aspect of actions that they are caused by an agent's mental state: their intention.

## Notable Philosophers

G. E. M. Anscombe's most important work is the monograph Intention (1957). The aim of Intention (1957) was to make plain the character of human action and will.(no content)Michael Bratman is best known for his development of the idea that "intention is a distinctive practical attitude marked by its pivotal role in planning for the future." His work in those areas led him to the Belief-Desire-Intention model that is used in many areas, including artificial intelligence, today.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis and extraction of key technologies and methodologies from the paper. Here's a summary:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (proposes new frameworks and concepts)

**Key Findings:**

The paper "On Reasoning about Values" has been analyzed and 8 major triples have been extracted:

1. **Wilfrid Sellars** - The key philosopher whose project the paper extends
2. **Intention** - Core concept examining how intention-expressions govern logical inferences
3. **Deontic logic** - The formal logical framework for analyzing moral ought statements
4. **Intersubjectivity** - The key philosophical problem addressed by the paper
5. **Rational agent** - The basis for defining the moral community
6. **We-intention** (NEW) - Novel concept proposed to solve the intersubjectivity problem
7. **Communitarianism** (NEW) - Theory of moral community developed from shared intentions
8. **Logic** - The methodological foundation using formal logical principles

The triples output file has been validated successfully with all Wikipedia URLs verified and the JSON structure confirmed.

Sources:
- [Wilfrid Sellars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilfrid_Sellars)

- [Rational agent](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rational_agent)
- [Communitarianism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communitarianism)
- [Logic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic)
